On 27/07/05, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> 
>  J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
> > Indeed. When I find I want a subclass to do "my parent's stuff, and a
> > little more", I often turn the parent's implementation into a Template
> > Method. If I find I need more than two layers of Template Method, then I
> > probably need to organize my test fixtures differently.
> 
> That's an interesting point. Can you give an example? Do you finalize 
> the template method in the parent?
> 
> David Saff
> 

The most relevant example is probably in JUnit itself. Look at the runBare() 
method in TestCase, which is the thing that guarantees the contract with 
setUp() and tearDown().

Interestingly, it isn't final, which is contrary to the typical 
implementation of Template Method in Java that I've come across.

James
